introduction.p: Suppose V is a vector space and S is a finite spanning set for V ( V = \Span S). In the previous chapter, we saw that if S is linearly dependent, then (at least) one vector can be removed from S, and the resulting smaller set will still be a spanning set. You can imagine repeating this process until finally you are left with a spanning set that is linearly independent.
This leads to the following definition.

li.title: basis for a vector space
li.p: a linearly independent spanning set for the space

introduction.p: In each of the following, determine whether S is a basis for V. If it is not a basis, make sure you know which property S violates, independence or spanning.

aside.title: Note
aside.p: A specific example could violate both, but we only need to know it violates one of the two properties to know it's not a basis.

task.p: V = the space of 3\times 3 lower triangular matrices,
V = \poly_3(\R), the space of all polynomials of degree 3 or less, S = \{1,x,x^2\}.

prelude.p: As discussed in the introduction to this discovery guide above, a spanning set that is not linearly independent contains redundant information in the form of vectors that are not actually needed to form a spanning set. This redundancy manifests itself in other ways, as the next discovery activity will demonstrate.

introduction.p: Consider the set S = \{(1,0),(1,1),(1,-1)\} of vectors in \R^2. This set spans \R^2 but is not linearly independent.

task.p: Since S spans \R^2, it is possible to express vector (3,-3) as a linear combination of the vectors in S.

Here is the redundant part. Demonstrate a different way to express (3,-3) as a linear combination of the vectors in S:
(3,-3) \; = \; (1,0) \; + \; (1,1) \; + \; (1,-1) .
How many different ways do you think there are to do this?

statement.p: Suppose V is a vector space, S = \{\uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\uvec{v}_3\} is a basis for V, and \uvec{w} is a vector in V.
Since S is a spanning set, there is a way to express \uvec{w} as linear combinations of the vectors in S: \uvec{w} = a_1\uvec{v}_1+a_2\uvec{v}_2+a_3\uvec{v}_3.

Suppose there were a different such expression: \uvec{w} = b_1\uvec{v}_1+b_2\uvec{v}_2+b_3\uvec{v}_3. Use the vector identity \uvec{w}-\uvec{w} = \zerovec and the two different expressions for \uvec{w} above to show that having these two different expressions violates the linear independence of S.

prelude.p: shows that when we have a basis S = \{\uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\dotsc,\uvec{v}_n\} for a vector space V, each vector in V has one unique expression as a linear combination of the vectors in S. For \uvec{w} = c_1\uvec{v}_1 + c_2\uvec{v}_2 + \dotsb + c_n\uvec{v}_n, the coefficients c_1,c_2,\dotsc,c_n are called the coordinates of \uvec{w} relative to Scoordinatesvectorcoordinates. Since these coordinates consist of n coefficients, we sometimes relate \uvec{w} to a vector in \R^n by collecting its coordinates into an n-tuple: \rmatrixOfplain{\uvec{w}}{S} = (c_1,c_2,\dotsc,c_n). This is called the coordinate vector of \uvec{w} relative to Scoordinate vectorvectorcoordinate.

introduction.p: In each of the following, determine the coordinate vector of \uvec{w} relative to the provided basis S for V.
In each of the following, determine which vector \uvec{w} in V has the given coordinate vector \rmatrixOfplain{\uvec{w}}{S}.
Coordinate vectors let us transfer vector algebra in a space V to the familiar space \R^n.
